author: By Rory Smith
title: Lionel Messi Wins Record Seventh Ballon d’Or
description: The Paris St.-Germain star capped a year in which he led Argentina to the Copa América title by edging Bayern Munich’s Robert Lewandowski.
content: Some of the most illustrious names in soccer’s long history only managed to win the Ballon d’Or, the sport’s most prestigious individual prize, once. George Best, Zinedine Zidane and Eúsebio all have just a single award to their names. Ronaldo, the great Brazilian striker, won two. Johan Cruyff, arguably the finest European player in history, has three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Climate Change Is Driving Some Albatrosses to ‘Divorce,’ Study Finds
description: Warming oceans are sending the monogamous sea birds farther afield to find food, putting stress on their breeding and prompting some to ditch their partners.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Albatrosses usually mate for life, making them among the most monogamous creatures on the planet. But climate change may be driving more of the birds to “divorce,” a study published last week by New Zealand’s Royal Society says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Iran Insists on Immediate Lifting of Sanctions as Nuclear Talks Resume
description: After five months, negotiations on restoring the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran resumed in Vienna, but with a harder line from the new Iranian government.
content: VIENNA — The setting was right, but the atmosphere chilly. After a break of more than five months, talks on reviving the 2015 Iran nuclear deal resumed on Monday in the Palais Coburg, the luxury hotel in Vienna where the original pact was signed with much fanfare, in a more optimistic time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: 4 takeaways from the first day of Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial.
description: In the coming weeks, jurors are expected to hear testimony from four women whom prosecutors say Jeffrey Epstein exploited for sex with Ms. Maxwell’s help.
content: The sex-trafficking trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, Jeffrey Epstein’s former romantic partner and employee, got underway in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday with opening statements and testimony from one of the pilots who flew Mr. Epstein’s private planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: What Is a ‘Comfort Creator’?
description: Move over, “Friends.” Turn off “The Office.” The new comforting media is streamers.
content: Among the legions of young people who spend their days watching content creators on Twitch and YouTube, a new honorific is on the rise: the comfort creator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Both parties claim victory as Honduras awaits election results.
description: Hondurans cast their vote Sunday in a largely peaceful, orderly election, that was nonetheless marred by deep polarization, technological shortcomings and fears of fraud.
content: Hondurans cast their vote Sunday in a largely peaceful, orderly election, that was nonetheless marred by deep polarization, technological shortcomings and fears of fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Inside the ‘Misinformation’ Wars
description: Journalists and academics are developing a new language for truth. The results are not always clearer.
content: On Friday afternoons this fall, top American news executives have dialed into a series of off-the-record Zoom meetings led by Harvard academics whose goal is to “help newsroom leaders fight misinformation and media manipulation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Decorative Ceramics
description: Artisanal ceramics can be just as special as fine art — and acquiring them is usually simpler and a lot less expensive.
content: Artisanal ceramics are having more than a moment. Interest in handcrafted clay objects has been surging for years, as a new generation of artisans has taken to the kilns and fired up a white-hot design trend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: What Makes a Wine Great? It’s Not Just Old and Complex.
description: It ought to have a sense of place, and it needs to refresh. Beyond that, great wines are those that best fit the particular occasion.
content: What makes a wine great? It’s a question that has intrigued anybody who has ever enjoyed a glass and paused to think about why that might be so.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: At Gyms, London Women Fuel Self-Defense Revival
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 29, 2021.
content: “It really just shows how unfair it is, because it is the responsibility for men to stop being predators. But now it’s ended up being our responsibility to pick up martial arts or whatever to stop these predators.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Adele Is No. 1 With a Huge Week, but Without a Million in Sales
description: “30” tops the Billboard album chart with the equivalent of 839,000 sales in the United States, leaving Taylor Swift’s “Reputation” as the last LP to cross the million mark.
content: The music business is full of gigantic numbers. Investors are pouring billions of dollars into funds to buy up song copyrights. Licensing clearinghouses like ASCAP and BMI process trillions of plays each year to collect and pay royalties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: A ‘Simpsons’ Episode Lampooned Chinese Censorship. In Hong Kong, It Vanished.
description: The episode mocked both Mao Zedong and the government’s efforts to suppress memory of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
content: HONG KONG — An episode of “The Simpsons” that ridicules Chinese government censorship appears to have been censored on Disney’s newly launched streaming service in Hong Kong, adding to fears about the shrinking space for free expression and criticism in this city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 12 in the N.F.L.
description: Tom Brady has help in Tampa Bay, the Bengals are forcing the issue in the A.F.C. North race, and the Rams have some soul-searching to do.
content: Here we go again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: A Heart-Healthy Way to Eat
description: Aim for an overall healthful dietary pattern, the American Heart Association advises, rather than focusing on “good” or “bad” foods.
content: There are no “good” foods and “bad” foods. Rather, it’s your overall dietary pattern that matters most when it comes to healthful eating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Pie Dish Made of Porcelain
description: Made In’s new pie plate comes with a stripe of blue or red and will accommodate recipes for nine-inch pies.
content: Baking and serving, with pie as the obvious candidate, are the designated purposes for this French dish, though it’s amenable to other foods, even unbaked. A new addition to Made In’s line of handsome yet utilitarian porcelain, it’s a standard 9 inches in diameter, inside, rim to rim, and 10.7 inches wide overall. The capacity is six cups. You select a stripe of blue or red on the edge. Give a homemade pie in it and let the recipient keep the dish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Companion, Ghislaine Maxwell, Goes on Trial
description: She is accused of recruiting and trafficking young girls for the disgraced financier.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at the sex-trafficking trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, which begins today. We’ll also update the story on the “Fearless Girl” statue. The statue’s permit from the city expires today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: A timeline of major events in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
description: Ghislaine Maxwell, a former girlfriend and longtime business associate of Jeffrey Epstein, was arrested nearly a year after his death.
content: The sex trafficking trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, a former girlfriend and longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, is set to begin Monday. Here are some of the events that led to the highly anticipated trial:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Enid Nemy
title: Adolfo, Designer Who Dressed Nancy Reagan, Dies at 98
description: Adolfo, who began as a milliner and took inspiration from Chanel, was also a favorite of New York society women.
content: Adolfo, who achieved international fashion fame as one of Nancy Reagan’s favorite designers during her years as first lady and who dressed many of society’s most prominent women for almost three decades, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Nicholas Fandos
title: Rep. Tom Suozzi Is Running for Governor of New York
description: Mr. Suozzi, who has positioned himself as a centrist, entered a crowded field of Democrats seeking to challenge the incumbent, Gov. Kathy Hochul.
content: Representative Thomas Suozzi, a Long Island Democrat, announced on Monday that he would enter the race for governor of New York, broadening the field of candidates running against the incumbent, Kathy Hochul, and becoming the first Democrat to take direct aim at her support among moderate suburban voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball’s Paradox: Money Is Flowing on the Brink of a Shutdown
description: Players are agreeing to huge contracts, and even struggling teams are getting in on the action. With a lockout looming, recalibration may be preferable to reinvention.
content: The Thanksgiving leftovers are still in the fridge, and Max Scherzer is already on his way to the Mets. That alone proves that the baseball off-season, which tends to unfold at a plodding pace, has come alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The Defense Department says Oklahoma National Guard must get vaccinated.
description: The governor had tried to exempt the troops from the federal vaccine requirement that applies to all service branches.
content: The Defense Department has rejected an attempt by the governor of Oklahoma to exclude the state’s National Guard from a federal vaccine mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiki Streitberger
title: Meet the Beauty Queens of Al Dhafra
description: Camel beauty contests take center stage at a celebration of Bedouin culture, held annually in the United Arab Emirates.
content: “Camel No. 1! Camel No. 1!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 3, Episode 7: Citizen Ken
description: Ken tries to have it both ways with a birthday party that is both absurdly over the top but disownably ironic. Unfortunately for him, it is more tragedy than farce.
content: The streaming services have been cluttered lately with “anatomy of a failure” documentaries, which detail the downfall of formerly white-hot companies like WeWork and LuLaRoe. In nearly all these docs, there’s a scene like Kendall’s 40th birthday party in this week’s episode of “Succession” — some preposterously lavish and borderline cultish shindig, celebrating a business culture about to collapse under its founding genius.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Here are the charges Ghislaine Maxwell faces.
description: The case against Ms. Maxwell is based on the accounts of four women whom prosecutors say she enticed to engage in sex acts with Jeffrey Epstein when they were underage.
content: Ghislaine Maxwell faces six counts in her federal trial, which relate to accusations that she facilitated the sexual exploitation of girls for her longtime companion, the disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
title: The Biden administration, under fire for supply chain woes, says stores will be fully stocked for the holidays.
description: President Biden has made a push to unclog ports, address trucker shortages and take other steps to alleviate the pressure created by consumers looking to buy couches, cars and electronics instead of eating out or going to theme parks.
content: President Biden told executives from some of the nation’s largest retailers on Monday that his administration was committed to partnering with them to untangle supply chains and ensure that American consumers can find everything they want this holiday season, as a surge in shopping tests an already strained global delivery system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: South African scientists caution against panic over the new variant.
description: Officials said that while they need more data to be sure, existing treatments and precautions seem to be effective against the Omicron variant.
content: South African health officials urged the public on Monday not to panic over the emergence of the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus, which appears to be driving a new wave of cases in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Markets Aren’t That Spooked by Omicron
description: Investors are re-pricing the risks of the latest coronavirus variant.
content: Scientists, doctors and public health officials are still assessing the danger posed by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, but markets are already jumping to conclusions. On Friday, markets fell on fears that the fast-spreading strain of the coronavirus first detected in South Africa, and which has now been found in more than a dozen countries, could throw the global economic recovery into reverse. Many countries have banned travel from countries in Southern Africa, while Israel, Japan and Morocco closed their borders to all outside travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Cora Engelbrecht
title: The U.K. announces Omicron cases and extends boosters to all adults.
description: The British government was widely criticized for a sluggish response to the Delta variant, and its reaction to Omicron came markedly quicker.
content: Britain expanded its vaccine booster program to all adults on Monday, stepping up its response to the newly discovered Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Farm Housing Mennonite Boys Engaged in Human Trafficking, Lawsuit Says
description: In a federal lawsuit against the Eastern Pennsylvania Mennonite Church, two plaintiffs said they were deprived of food and restrained with zip ties at a forced-labor farm.
content: Two men filed a federal lawsuit this month against the Eastern Pennsylvania Mennonite Church, saying that they were victims of a human trafficking scheme while they lived at a forced-labor farm for troubled boys run by a church member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘He Sold Away His People’s Heritage. He’s in the Jungle to Get It Back.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a Cambodian temple looter who is helping identify and reclaim stolen artifacts. Then, they will discuss what museums and private collectors should do with looted artifacts in their collections.
content: Featured Article: “He Sold Away His People’s Heritage. He’s in the Jungle to Get It Back.” Tom Mashberg
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Who Owns a Recipe? A Plagiarism Claim Has Cookbook Authors Asking.
description: U.S. copyright law protects all kinds of creative material, but recipe creators are mostly powerless in an age and a business that are all about sharing.
content: In 2011, the cookbook editor Rux Martin noticed something unsettling on the cover of a women’s magazine: a vanilla cupcake decorated with yellow, cream and white jelly beans arranged to mimic corn kernels, a faux butter slice made from a yellow fruit chew, and black and white sugars to imitate salt and pepper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Emily Ratajkowski Isn’t Quite Ready to Quit Profiting Off the Male Gaze
description: The model on wielding beauty and power in the age of Instagram.
content: Emily Ratajkowski is winning in the Instagram era: She has 28.6 million followers and has spent more than half her life making a living as a model. But even at her level of success, she still wonders: When you make a living off your desirability, is the power of your body ever just yours?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Cookbook From Chris Cheung, of East Wind Snack Shop
description: New York’s Chinatowns are the inspiration for his first book, “Damn Good Chinese Food.”
content: Having burnished his culinary skills in the kitchens of Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Nobu Matsuhisa, the chef Chris Cheung returned to the food of Manhattan’s Chinatown, where he was born and raised, to create his casual East Wind Snack Shops in Brooklyn. In “Damn Good Chinese Food,” his first cookbook, Mr. Cheung is your guide to Chinatown (as he was for Anthony Bourdain) and its vibrant markets. His book outlines equipment and techniques, and gives 50 recipes for dishes from the Chinese American canon, many with refinements. These include pungent sweet and sour pork Peking style; three cups cauliflower, which cleverly swaps out the usual chicken for the vegetable; designer egg drop soup; briny black bean clams; pork belly bao buns; and many, many dumplings, explaining the Chinatown pedigree and his personal take. Be prepared to use MSG; Mr. Cheung makes a cultural argument for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch police arrest a couple who fled quarantine and boarded a plane.
description: One of the pair tested positive for the coronavirus after they arrived on a flight from South Africa. They were quarantined at a hotel.
content: The Dutch military police arrested a couple on Sunday who were about to fly out of the Netherlands when they were supposed to be in quarantine. One of the pair had tested positive for the coronavirus two days earlier after arriving from South Africa, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: A New Publishing Platform for Comic Books Will Give Creators a Greater Stake
description: Zestworld, which counts Alexis Ohanian as a supporter, will allow comic book writers and artists to present new work and reap the benefits.
content: Many comic book characters anchor global franchises, but their creators — or the writers and artists who helped make them popular — have not always shared in that success. Zestworld, a new subscription-based platform that is set to be introduced in early 2022, is hoping to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith
title: Elizabeth Holmes Says Former Boyfriend Abused Her
description: Ms. Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, blamed Ramesh Balwani, the former No. 2 at the company.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Taking a deep breath, Elizabeth Holmes briefly crumpled her face as she spoke, her voice breaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Just When We Thought It Was Safe to Go Back in the Water
description: The Omicron variant is creating a lot of anxiety.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, I hope you had a beautiful Thanksgiving. We made two big discoveries on Thursday. The first was creamed dried sweet corn. The second was the Omicron variant of Covid, which was first identified by scientists in South Africa. I guess you could say the corn went down better than the cron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Finding Purpose by Giving Back
description: Whether helping people stay clean and safe, pursue their educational dreams or find the aid they need, volunteers make a difference.
content: When Shamma Goodrich moved to New York in 2015, she was struck by the homelessness in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Adele and Summer Walker: Our Season of Romantic Discontent
description: New chart-topping albums from the two singers serve as raw excavations of relationships gone bad.
content: Adele’s new album, “30,” is about the dissolution of her marriage, and also the flickers of romantic renewal that have subsequently given her hope. But the most lively parts, the most vivid moments, are the darkest ones. The hollow pain of heartbreak activates something in her — the more self-lacerating she gets, the more sumptuous her singing becomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Breaking Barriers: The Life of Lee Elder
description: Elder was the author of “a signature moment” in professional golf.
content: At a dinner at Pebble Beach in 2019 to honor Lee Elder with the Bob Jones Award for sportsmanship, bestowed by the United States Golf Association, the commentator Jim Nantz told the golfer in a speech: “Your life will have meaning for years and centuries to come.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Kate Conger and Cade Metz
title: Who Is Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s New C.E.O.?
description: A longtime Twitter insider and a confidant of co-founder Jack Dorsey, Mr. Agrawal takes over as the social media company confronts various challenges.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Jack Dorsey, then Twitter’s executive chairman, pushed the company to build out its machine learning and artificial intelligence capabilities in 2014, he turned to an engineer, Parag Agrawal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Forget Bloody Marys. This Brunch Has Caviar, and Lots of It.
description: At Hancock St. in the West Village, an uncommonly affordable caviar service is available.
content: Fine caviar is a year-round indulgence, but especially so at holiday time. At Hancock St. restaurant in the West Village, which opened earlier this year, John McDonald, the owner, and his chef, Ryan Schmidtberger, offer an uncommonly affordable caviar service. For $165 at dinner and brunch, a rock-bottom price even compared with what retailers are charging, a four-ounce tin of nice Russian osetra, enough for four or even six people, is presented on ice in a cut glass dish with homemade potato chips, brioche toast and crème fraîche. “I was able to negotiate a good price so I’m passing it along,” Mr. McDonald said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson
title: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
description: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.
content: KASULO, Democratic Republic of Congo — A man in a pinstripe suit with a red pocket square walked around the edge of a giant pit one April afternoon where hundreds of workers often toil in flip-flops, burrowing deep into the ground with shovels and pickaxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Doyle Hamm, Who Survived a Bungled Execution, Dies in Prison at 64
description: The failed lethal injection for Mr. Hamm, who was terminally ill, amounted to what his lawyer said was a case of cruel and unusual punishment.
content: Doyle Hamm, a convicted murderer who in 2018 became the third death row inmate in America to survive a botched execution by lethal injection, died on Sunday in the William C. Holman Correctional Facility near Atmore, in southern Alabama. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cornish Pasties and More at the DeKalb Market
description: At Oggie’s, a new stand in Brooklyn, petite sweet pies are also on the menu.
content: Home-baked fruit pies were a way of life for Jerry Brimeyer, who grew up on an Iowa farm. Later, when business took him to England, he discovered Cornish pasties, the savory hand pies wrapped in flaky pastry. He’s joined the two at Oggie’s, his addition to DeKalb Market in Brooklyn. He sells assorted pasties and sweet miniature open-faced pies. The pasties, big, well-stuffed baked half-moons ($8 to $10), come with pulled pork; steak and mushrooms; chicken and vegetables; Mediterranean vegetables; ham with cheese and scrambled eggs; among others. The dessert pies ($3.50) include apple, sweet and sour cherry, blueberry, pecan, and banoffee. All are ready to eat and suitable for reheating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levy
title: A Climbing Award That May Be a Winner’s Last
description: The Piolet d’Or, or Golden Ice Axe, is alpine climbing’s biggest award. But whether it honors or encourages risk is debated in the sport.
content: High on Lunag Ri in Nepal, the Austrian climber David Lama started worrying that he might lose his toes. The cold on the 22,621-foot mountain was as bad as anything he had ever experienced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Dave Philipps
title: Pentagon Chief Orders New Inquiry Into U.S. Airstrike That Killed Dozens in Syria
description: The decision follows a New York Times investigation that described allegations that top officials had sought to conceal civilian casualties.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Monday ordered a new high-level investigation into a U.S. airstrike in Syria in 2019 that killed dozens of women and children, the Pentagon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: In Scotland, Serving Halibut for a Better Planet
description: Scottish cooks and diners are putting sustainable fish and shellfish on the plate in a tangible (and delicious) move to curb the effects of climate change.
content: GLASGOW — Inver restaurant is but a speck on the longest sea loch in Scotland. From its windows, a diner can see the remnants of a 15th-century castle and the rolling hills of the Highlands, but the breakout star is not the view. It’s a meaty halibut head that the chef Pam Brunton grills over wood and finishes with melted homemade ’nduja and a tangle of grilled green onions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Shop Where Kids Are Encouraged to Make a Mess
description: Cricket’s Candy Creations in Hudson Square holds candy workshops for children, and there’s “slime”.
content: Cricket’s Candy Creations, a new outlet for children’s creativity, experimentation and messing around, has opened in Hudson Square. Cricket Azima, a chef and entrepreneur who specializes in working with children and runs the Creative Kitchen, with online and in-person activities, and the Kids Food Festival, with events in various locations nationwide, has opened a spacious storefront studio for children’s workshops. Several classes of 10 to 12 children can be held at a time. It involves edible finger paints, candy “slime,” chocolate and more to make all sorts of candy items, including jewelry, candy food like pizza, crafts and treats. Sessions are $65 to $80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: With Omicron’s Arrival, Stocks Will Again Hang on Headlines
description: Stocks rose on Monday, but analysts expect a bumpy ride for share prices while experts assess whether existing vaccines will be effective against the new variant.
content: On Wall Street, the end of the pandemic appeared tantalizingly close just a week ago. There were positive signs the economy was rebounding, and investors’ biggest worry was how quickly the Federal Reserve would pivot away from the market-boosting policies that have helped stocks soar in the past year and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Virgil Abloh, Ambassador and Infiltrator
description: Look around at the way young men now think about clothes, design and music, and you’ll see him everywhere.
content: In recent years, it could often appear as if there were several Virgil Ablohs, all working at the same time. There were the multiple annual collections of Louis Vuitton, where he was the artistic director of men’s wear, and Off-White, his own label, which he’d founded while still in the orbit of Kanye West. There were the seemingly endless collaborations, with brands as disparate as Nike, Ikea, Evian, Rimowa, Vitra, Chrome Hearts and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: An Auto Show for the Raddest Cars of the ’80s and ’90s
description: Nostalgia mixes with tape decks and car phones at RADwood events that aim to capture “the essence of a bodacious era.”
content: Everything was awesome. The music was fresh, the movies were dope and the hair was big. The cars? Rad, then and now. Maybe especially now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Boebert Reaches Out to Omar After Incendiary Video, Escalating a Feud
description: Representative Lauren Boebert made an overture to Representative Ilhan Omar after suggesting that the Muslim lawmaker was a terrorism threat. The call did not go well.
content: WASHINGTON — Some gulfs are too wide to bridge, but it appeared at first as if Representative Lauren Boebert, the far-right Republican from Colorado, was trying to do so on Monday when she reached out to Representative Ilhan Omar, the progressive Democrat from Minnesota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Gulpilil, Famed Aboriginal Actor, Dies at 68
description: In a career that began with the film “Walkabout” 50 years ago, he was acclaimed for changing the way Australia’s Indigenous people were portrayed and viewed.
content: David Gulpilil, an Indigenous Australian who found film stardom as a teenager in 1971 when he was featured in “Walkabout” and went on to become Australia’s most famous Aboriginal actor, appearing in dramas like “Charlie’s Country,” for which he won a best-actor award at the Cannes Film Festival in 2014, and comedies like the 1986 hit “Crocodile Dundee,” died on Monday in Murray Bridge, in South Australia. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About Omicron
description: California officials are watching for evidence of the new coronavirus variant and increasing testing at airports.
content: Chances are that headlines about a new and worrisome coronavirus variant interrupted the blissful haze of your holiday weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Tracing the Trail of Amazon Deforestation
description: A Times investigation married hourslong stakeouts with data reporting and found that it’s all too easy for hides from illegally deforested ranches to reach the global marketplace.
content: In July 2021, Manuela Andreoni, a Pulitzer Center reporting fellow at The New York Times, camped out for hours outside a slaughterhouse close to the Jaci-Paraná reserve in Brazil. She was tracking a truck that she suspected was delivering hides from cattle kept on illegally deforested ranches to a supplier of American automobile seat makers. A few days earlier, Victor Moriyama, a photographer working for The Times, nearly stepped on a poisonous snake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Latest on Omicron
description: What should you assume about the new variant?
content: The public reaction to new Covid-19 variants has followed a familiar cycle. People tend to assume the worst about two different questions — whether the variant leads to faster transmission of the Covid virus and whether it causes more severe illness among infected people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Omicron increases inflation uncertainty, the Fed chair will tell lawmakers.
description: Jerome H. Powell, who will appear before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, also plans to tell lawmakers that price gains could last well into 2022, according to prepared remarks.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, will tell lawmakers on Tuesday that inflation is likely to last well into next year and that the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus creates more uncertainty around the economic outlook, according to a copy of his prepared remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Fragmented Reactions Hinder Global Fight Against Omicron Variant
description: Almost two years into the pandemic, finger-pointing, lack of coordination, sparse information and fear are once again influencing policy.
content: ROME — In a wrenchingly familiar cycle of tracking first cases, pointing fingers and banning travel, nations worldwide reacted Monday to the Omicron variant of the coronavirus in the piecemeal fashion that has defined — and hobbled — the pandemic response all along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Looking for the Good War’ Says Our Nostalgia for World War II Has Done Real Harm
description: Elizabeth D. Samet demystifies the cultural narrative that has shrouded the historical reality.
content: Toward the end of “Looking for the Good War,” Elizabeth D. Samet’s discerning new book about the gauzy mythology that has shrouded the historical reality of World War II, she reminds us of the 2019 speech that then-President Trump gave at Normandy, on the 75th anniversary of D-Day. Some listeners were so surprised by the solemnity of Trump’s words that they eagerly welcomed it as evidence that he was donning the mantle of dignified statesman. But Samet, a professor of English at West Point who has previously written about teaching the literature of warfare, refuses to grade on a curve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden calls Omicron a ‘cause for concern, not a cause for panic.’
description: The variant has yet to be detected in the United States, and crucial questions about it remain.
content: President Biden sought to reassure the nation on Monday about the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus as crucial questions about it remain, telling Americans that the variant is “a cause for concern, not a cause for panic,” and that his administration was working with vaccine manufacturers to modify vaccines and booster shots should that prove necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Portugal detects 13 cases of Omicron tied to a soccer team.
description: The team, Belenenses, took part in a game that had to be abandoned after a Covid outbreak reduced the number of eligible players. One infected player had recently returned from South Africa.
content: Portugal on Monday said it had identified 13 cases of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, all tied to Belenenses, a soccer club that was forced to take part in a top-flight game over the weekend that was abandoned while in progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Black Friday sales were up, but reflected the challenges facing retailers.
description: Drawn by deals, consumers spread out their spending in the weeks leading up to the day after Thanksgiving.
content: The Black Friday weekend was a success for retailers, but reflected challenges in the supply chain and the prevalence of early deals in October, which prompted customers to spread out their spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: With Political Memes, the Medium Matters
description: Dissecting the visual aspects of the violent video circulated by Representative Paul Gosar.
content: In October, a video depicting the murder of a United States congresswoman made a brief, explosive Twitter debut. The 90-second clip, created by Representative Paul Gosar, Republican of Arizona, was a doctored anime depicting Mr. Gosar (flying around like a superhero) slashing the throat of a character with the face of Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York (and also attacking President Biden with swords).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael Gold, Grace Ashford and Dana Rubinstein
title: Chris Cuomo Played Outsize Role in Ex-Gov. Cuomo’s Defense
description: Chris Cuomo, the CNN host, participated in strategy discussions and shared a tip on at least one woman who had accused his brother, Andrew Cuomo, of sexual harassment.
content: Thousands of pages of new evidence and sworn testimony released on Monday show the extent to which former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo relied on a group of allies, including his younger brother, the CNN host Chris Cuomo, to strategize how to deflect and survive a cascade of sexual harassment charges that eventually engulfed him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel to Propose Charging Former Trump Official With Contempt
description: The committee investigating the Capitol riot will consider recommending criminal charges against Jeffrey Clark, a former Justice Department official.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol moved on Monday to begin contempt of Congress proceedings against Jeffrey Clark, a former Justice Department official involved in President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election, setting a vote this week on recommending criminal charges for his refusal to cooperate with a subpoena from the panel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Virgil Abloh Shocked the System
description: His designs may not always have been trailblazing, yet his disruptions of a static industry altered fashion for good.
content: Right out of the gate after being hired as artistic director of Louis Vuitton mens’s wear, Virgil Abloh scored a whopping commercial hit with an iridescent plastic tote bag, or “keepall,” he called the Prism. In the hours since Mr. Abloh’s death at 41, of a rare cancer, was made public, people struggled to characterize a man whose contributions to the industry extended far beyond any individual design. He was variously termed kaleidoscopic, a Renaissance man, a protean force in the history of fashion, and yet, looking back on his brief tenure at the apex of the business, what seems clear is that the word that best describes Mr. Abloh was there all along. He had provided it himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch
title: Twitter’s Jack Dorsey Steps Down From C.E.O. Role
description: The social media pioneer, whose name has become synonymous with the company, was replaced by Twitter’s chief technology officer, Parag Agrawal.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Dorsey stepped down on Monday as chief executive of Twitter, the social media site he co-founded in 2006 and navigated through the tumultuous years of the Trump administration and increasing calls for regulation from lawmakers around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 6: Dreams and Ghosts
description: This week’s episode revolves largely around professional aspirations and the messy entanglements that can result from them.
content: This week’s episode begins with a fever dream that ends with Issa recreating a viral meme. She is fantasizing about talking to Lawrence and Condola at the hospital. In the clouds of her animated mind, she shoots Elijah toward a trash can after kicking Condola into a laundry pile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: ‘Her Heart Was Beating Too’: The Women Who Died After Abortion Bans
description: It should not take a high-profile death to expose just how much is at risk when medicine is hamstrung by politics, religion or culture.
content: In 2012, Savita Halappanavar, a 31-year-old married dentist, appeared at Ireland’s University Hospital Galway in pain. She was 17 weeks pregnant and miscarrying. According to Dr. Halappanavar’s husband, hospital staff said that there was no saving the pregnancy, but they refused to intercede because her fetus still had a heartbeat. She was told her only option was to wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Omicron, Twitter, Cuomo: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Biden Military Review Leaves Troops Where They Are, for Now
description: The report sidesteps a decision on what to do about troop numbers in Somalia, after President Donald J. Trump’s decision to pull out last year.
content: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials announced the results of a nearly yearlong review of the country’s military presence abroad on Monday, but the recommendation included few changes in the positioning of American troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Chelsea Daniel, Rachelle Bonja, Sydney Harper, Rachel Quester, Robert Jimison, Lisa Tobin, Lisa Chow and Chris Wood
title: A Prosecutor’s Winning Strategy in the Ahmaud Arbery Case
description: The three men charged with killing Ahmaud Arbery were found guilty of murder. We explore how the prosecution secured this verdict from a mostly white jury.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Omicron moves across the world.
content: The new coronavirus variant named Omicron by the W.H.O. is showing up across the world, prompting stock market tumbles and border closures. It has so far been identified in Britain, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, the Netherlands and other places, usually in people who had recently returned from southern Africa. Here’s a map of cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Websites Force Users to Prove How Old They Are?
description: Major parts of the internet are being locked behind stricter digital age checks to protect children. Is that a good thing?
content: Note to teachers: Please preview the featured article to make sure it is appropriate for your students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: College Football’s ‘Great Man Theory’ Gets a New Test at U.S.C.
description: Southern California hired Lincoln Riley from Oklahoma, which is now looking for his successor. The carousel seemed to spin harder and faster than ever as programs looked for saviors.
content: College football’s allegiance to its version of the great man theory, to the idea that a single coach can prove transformative, has always been a matter of convenience. But rarely have the sport’s fickle feelings about it been so apparent as these past few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Confronting the Omicron variant.
content: Israel, Morocco, Japan and South Korea closed off foreign travel. European nations shut their borders specifically to travelers from southern Africa. A U.S. governor declared a state of emergency, without cases having been reported in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: South Africa Deserves a Big, Fat Prize
description: Rewarding the nation for detecting and reporting the Omicron variant would give other countries an incentive to report new variants.
content: South Africa is paying a heavy price for its good deed of telling the world about the Omicron variant of the virus that causes Covid-19. Many countries, including Britain and the United States, are restricting air travel to and from the nation. That will do more damage to an economy already weakened by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Horse Troughs, Hot Tubs and Hashtags: Baptism Is Getting Wild
description: In some evangelical churches, a once-staid ritual is returning to its informal roots — and things sometimes get “a little rowdy” along the way.
content: Russell Moore’s baptism in 1983 was a decorous occasion, or at least as decorous as possible when the main event consists of being plunged underwater in front of one’s entire church. The ceremony took place in a formal baptistery inside his family’s Mississippi church, with a painting of the Jordan River — where Jesus was baptized by John the Baptist — behind the tank. An organ played softly in the background. Mr. Moore wore a long white robe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Stanley Reed
title: Europe Revisits Nuclear Power as Climate Deadlines Loom
description: While wind and solar ramp up, several countries, including France and Britain, are looking to expand their nuclear energy programs. Germany and others aren’t so enthusiastic.
content: PARIS — European countries desperate for a long-term and reliable source of energy to help reach ambitious climate goals are turning to an answer that caused earlier generations to shudder: nuclear power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Go Gaga Over Panettone
description: The restaurant Gucci Osteria, by the chef Massimo Bottura, sells two panettone, while in New York, a festival devoted to the cake will be held in Queens.
content: “The House of Gucci” is not exactly a food flick, so the panettone from Gucci Osteria da Massimo Bottura in Beverly Hills, Calif., doesn’t figure in the plot. But Mr. Bottura’s executive chef, Mattia Agazzi, worked with a panettone master, Roy Schvartzapel, on two versions of the tall eggy dome of Christmas cake for the restaurant on Rodeo Drive that they’re also selling online. One is studded with candied orange and raisins, the other with orange and hazelnut gianduja, each in a decorative tin designed by Gucci. And if you would like to explore other panettone options, this year the first New York City panettone festival will be held in Queens, with more than a dozen chefs baking varieties like white fig with chocolate; saffron; or apricot, along with other holiday treats for sampling and sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: The Patriots’ Dynasty May Not Be Over After All
description: New England thrashed the Tennessee Titans for its sixth consecutive victory, improving to 8-4 and taking over first place in the A.F.C. East.
content: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Those who play football in New England agree to abide by certain tenets, or else. They must do their jobs. They must not worry about what they cannot control. They must not bring undue attention upon themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Under the Radar Festival Returns, Smaller but Still Funky
description: The experimental festival at the Public Theater will return in person with fewer shows and, for the first time, performances outside New York City.
content: The Under the Radar festival, the Public Theater’s annual showcase for experimental theater, will return in person next year, Jan. 12-30. The event, now in its 18th year, will feature nearly two dozen artists, with performances held at the Public and Mabou Mines in Manhattan as well as a venue in upstate New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Colton Underwood Comes Out and Comes Clean
description: The former “Bachelor” star announced he is gay on national TV in April. A new Netflix reality series seeks to share his journey and address the criticism.
content: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Spend 10 seconds with Colton Underwood, and you get why “The Bachelor” figured he was a home run. He has a boy-next-door smile and an aw-shucks manner. He’s brawny. He hikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Guadagnino
title: Looking at Surrealist Art in Our Own Surreal Age
description: When viewed as a vehicle for various forms of liberation, the movement remains highly resonant even a century after its heyday.
content: “SURREALISM” IS ONE of those buzzwords, like “curate” or “groundbreaking,” that has been rendered effectively meaningless through overuse. In his 1924 “Manifesto of Surrealism,” the writer André Breton defined the term most succinctly as an attempt to resolve “these two states, dream and reality, which are seemingly so contradictory,” though its true origins came earlier, with the rise of Dada, an artistic movement that emerged in Zurich in 1916, and which favored the absurd over the logical. It was the exact middle of World War I, and there was a sense among Dada’s proponents that linear thinking hadn’t gotten society anywhere good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: What we know about Omicron.
content: We asked Dr. Anthony Fauci last week why we haven’t seen the rise of a powerful new coronavirus variant since Delta. Just a few days later, we got a possible answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Czech president appoints a new prime minister — from inside a transparent cube.
description: President Milos Zeman tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and went into isolation, delaying the ceremony for three days.
content: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic, who tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday, appointed the country’s new prime minister on Sunday while sitting inside a transparent cube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Christina Anderson
title: Sweden Elects Its First Female Leader — for Second Time in a Week
description: The Swedish Parliament elected Magdalena Andersson as prime minister by a narrow margin. She was first elected last week, but her government soon collapsed over a budget dispute.
content: Last week, Magdalena Andersson became Sweden’s first female prime minister — for all of seven hours. Less than a week later, the country’s Parliament has re-elected her to the post, with the hope that she will be able to stick around longer this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Stamping Bar Codes on Cells to Solve Medical Mysteries
description: By tracking every cell in an organism, scientists are working out why certain cancer treatments fail, which could lead to improved medicine.
content: No one really knew why some patients with a white blood cell cancer called chronic lymphocytic leukemia, or C.L.L., relapsed after treatment and got a second cancer. Were some cancer cells just resistant?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Hannon
title: Could Roads Recharge Electric Cars? The Technology May Be Close.
description: But challenges await, including technical issues, regulatory barriers and many miles of highway.
content: Electric vehicles are getting a lot of buzz. Yet sales of electric vehicles, or EVs, are expected to amount to less than 4 percent of passenger vehicle sales in the United States in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geordon Wollner
title: What’s on TV This Week: Willy Wonka and a ‘West Side Story’ Special
description: “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory” airs on AMC. And ABC hosts a special on “West Side Story.”
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 29-Dec. 5. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Omicron carries scary mutations. That doesn’t mean they work well together.
description: Mutations can work together to make a virus more fearsome, but they can also cancel one another out. This phenomenon, called epistasis, is why scientists are reluctant to speculate on Omicron.
content: The Omicron variant of the coronavirus has alarmed many scientists because of the sheer number of genetic mutations it carries — about 50 in all, including at least 26 that are unique to it. But more does not necessarily mean worse: Mutations sometimes work together to make a virus more fearsome, but they may also cancel one another out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Clearview AI, a facial recognition company, is fined for breach of Britain’s privacy laws.
description: The Information Commissioner’s Office said it fined Clearview AI for failing to inform British residents that it was collecting billions of photos from sites including Facebook, Instagram and LinkedIn to build its facial recognition software.
content: Britain’s independent data privacy authority on Monday fined the facial recognition company Clearview AI 17 million pounds, or $22.6 million, for failing to comply with the nation’s data protection laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Taliban and 9/11 Families Fight for Billions in Frozen Afghan Funds
description: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly 20 years ago, about 150 family members of Sept. 11 victims sought a measure of justice for their losses by suing a list of targets like Al Qaeda and the Taliban. A decade later, a court found the defendants liable by default and ordered them to pay damages now worth about $7 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: What Is Cardiac Angiosarcoma?
description: Virgil Abloh, the celebrated fashion designer, died at 41 after being diagnosed with the rare cancer. Here’s what we know about it.
content: On Sunday, Virgil Abloh, a noted designer and artistic director of men’s fashion at Louis Vuitton, died at 41 in Chicago after a two-year battle with cardiac angiosarcoma. According to a statement released on his Instagram account, Mr. Abloh was diagnosed with the rare cancer in 2019 and underwent a number of treatments before he died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard and Grace Ashford
title: Can New York Really Get to 100% Clean Energy by 2040?
description: Clean power supply is being generated in upstate New York, but it is not making its way to New York City, the area that relies most heavily on power from fossil fuels.
content: Two years ago New York committed to the nation’s most ambitious climate goals to shift away from the fossil fuels heating the planet and create a new, electrified economy that stops adding to climate change by 2050. State agencies and private companies went to work building hundreds of wind and solar farms to power businesses, vehicles and homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: In Bill Cosby Case, Supreme Court Is Asked to Toss Ruling That Freed Him
description: The prosecutors who brought the 2018 sexual assault case are appealing the decision in June by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court that overturned the jury verdict.
content: Prosecutors who say Bill Cosby belongs in prison are asking the United States Supreme Court to throw out an appellate court ruling earlier this year that overturned his 2018 conviction for sexual assault on due process grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Joan Suazo
title: Honduras Election Front-Runner Vows New Era but Is Tied to Past
description: Xiomara Castro, headed toward becoming her country’s next president, promises to expunge its legacy of corruption, but change may be tempered by her establishment ties and conservative opposition.
content: MEXICO CITY — The Honduras opposition candidate, Xiomara Castro, inched closer to an astounding presidential victory on Monday, promising a new era of democratic inclusion in a nation where despair has driven hundreds of thousands to the U.S. border seeking refuge in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: As Antiviral Pills Arrive, Can Testing Keep Up?
description: The pills must be given early in the course of infection, which means access to timely, accurate test results will be crucial.
content: Before the end of the year, Americans who contract the coronavirus may be able to purchase an effective treatment on a trip to their neighborhood pharmacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Movie theaters must ‘urgently’ rethink the experience, a study says.
description: Nearly half of the prepandemic audience hasn’t returned, research shows, and 8 percent may be gone forever.
content: LOS ANGELES — About 49 percent of prepandemic moviegoers are no longer buying tickets. Some of them, roughly 8 percent, have likely been lost forever. To win back the rest, multiplex owners must “urgently” rethink pricing and customer perks in addition to focusing on coronavirus safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tali Farhadian Weinstein
title: Kyle Rittenhouse, Travis McMichael and the Problem of ‘Self Defense’
description: More guns, no matter in whose hands, will create more standoffs, more intimidation, more death sanctioned in the eyes of the law.
content: As pundits and legal experts consider why Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted of murder, many have focused on the prosecution’s choices — and possible errors — in the case, or else on the rulings of the presiding judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Public Flagpole, a Christian Flag and the First Amendment
description: The Supreme Court will decide whether Boston, which allows many kinds of groups to raise flags outside its City Hall, can reject one bearing the Latin cross.
content: WASHINGTON — There are three flagpoles in front of Boston’s City Hall. One flies the American flag, and the second that of Massachusetts. What appears on the third is at issue in a case the Supreme Court will hear in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: hegemony
description: This word has appeared in 57 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: As Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial Begins, Epstein’s Shadow Looms Large
description: Ms. Maxwell’s sex trafficking trial in Manhattan, which starts on Monday, is widely seen as a proxy for the courtroom reckoning that her longtime partner never received.
content: On the first floor of the federal courthouse in Manhattan hangs an unusual art exhibit: framed courtroom illustrations of terrorists, mobsters and corrupt politicians with names like Yousef, Gotti and Silver who had all appeared before judges there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: No Credit Score? No Problem! Just Hand Over More Data.
description: To determine your risk, start-ups are applying technology to data points as various as your college and the mileage on the used car you want to buy.
content: For decades, the arbiters of creditworthiness have been two powerful groups: the Big Three credit bureaus, which keep files on roughly 200 million consumers, and score creators like FICO, which turn that raw data into a three-digit key to credit cards, car loans, mortgages and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danna Lorch
title: You’re Allowed to Complain About Your Kids, Even After Infertility
description: ‘It is 100 percent normal to feel conflicted even if you went to hell and back to become a parent.’
content: I clamped my hands over my ears as the obstetrician cranked up the volume on the ultrasound machine. After three pregnancy losses, I was convinced that we’d be met only with static.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What Kind of Dog Is He? DNA Can Tell Me Only So Much.
description: There are some mysteries that even genetic science can’t explain.
content: NASHVILLE — Rascal is a small dog, not quite 13 pounds, longer than he is tall. His feet point in one direction, his knees point in another, and his fur is equally mismatched: short and curly in places, long and curly in other places, and just plain long or just plain short in still others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The Packers Use Familiar Hands to Best the New-Look Rams
description: Green Bay’s Aaron Rodgers relied on veterans to beat the Rams, who had stockpiled talented stars like Von Miller and Odell Beckham Jr. to contend for the N.F.C. title.
content: GREEN BAY, Wis. — At the start of November, the Los Angeles Rams were 7-1 and in the hunt for a bye in the first round of the playoffs. The team’s general manager, Les Snead, built on that momentum by trading for the star linebacker Von Miller and signing wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. after his release from the Cleveland Browns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Lola Fadulu
title: De Blasio reminds New Yorkers to wear masks indoors.
description: “We’re doubling down” on current mask guidance, the mayor said. He also extended the city’s vaccine mandate to cover workers in child care settings and early intervention programs.
content: With the Omicron variant of the coronavirus appearing likely to be detected in New York City any day now, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday that he was strengthening the city health department’s standing advice that New Yorkers — both vaccinated and unvaccinated — wear masks in indoor public settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Los hondureños votaron en paz y ahora esperan resultados con temores de fraude
description: Los hondureños emitieron sus votos en una jornada que transcurrió en su mayoría en paz y en orden a pesar de la polarización, algunos fallos tecnológicos y temores de fraude.
content: Los hondureños emitieron sus votos en una jornada que transcurrió en su mayoría en paz y en orden a pesar de la polarización, algunos fallos tecnológicos y temores de fraude.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flood-Drenched British Columbians Fear This Is the New Normal
description: Washed-out roads and destroyed bridges are just some of the devastation afflicting residents of the western province and could signal what climate change will bring in the future.
content: PRINCETON, British Columbia — With light drizzle in the air, a young woman wiped away tears as she stood on the veranda of a newly renovated gray and white house. Its toilets and other plumbing fixtures sat beside her. Most of the house’s other contents were on the street in a muddy pile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: She Fled North Korea for Freedom. Then She Was Arrested.
description: The case of “Chrysanthemum” offers a rare look at the covert battle the rival Koreas are waging over North Korean defectors living in the South.
content: SEOUL — Song Chun-son, a duck farm worker, endured two and a half years in a North Korean labor camp and said she was later coerced to work for its secret police, the Ministry of State Security. Then she defected to South Korea in 2018. She studied to become a caretaker for nursing home patients while working part time as a waitress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Matthew McConaughey Says He Will Not Run for Texas Governor
description: With about two weeks before the candidate filing deadline for the Texas primary, the actor said a run for office is “a path that I’m choosing not to take at this moment.”
content: The actor and author Matthew McConaughey announced on Sunday that he would not run for governor of Texas for now, after months of weighing whether he would seek the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods Rules Out a Full-Time Return to the PGA Tour
description: In a half-hour video interview with Golf Digest, Woods, who was badly injured in a car crash early this year, said he hopes to recover enough to play sporadically in tour events.
content: Tiger Woods hopes to play on the PGA Tour again, though never as a full-time player, something he called “an unfortunate reality” that he has accepted, according to a 30-minute video interview with Golf Digest posted online Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: A judge temporarily blocks a vaccine mandate for health workers in 10 states.
description: The injunction is another setback for the Biden administration after an appeals court suspended its vaccine mandate for large employers earlier this month.
content: A federal judge on Monday temporarily blocked the Biden administration’s coronavirus vaccine mandate for health care workers in the 10 states that had filed a lawsuit against the government this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith
title: Elizabeth Holmes Testimony: Updates From Day 4
description: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, took the stand for a fourth day on Monday.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, took the stand for a fourth day on Monday to defend herself in a fraud trial that has been billed as a test of start-up hubris and hype.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: As World Shuts Borders to Stop Omicron, Japan Offers a Cautionary Tale
description: Japan, which has been very cautious throughout the pandemic, is again barring all nonresident foreigners. There is an economic and human cost.
content: TOKYO — With the emergence of the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus late last week, countries across the globe rushed to close their borders to travelers from southern Africa, even in the absence of scientific information about whether such measures were necessary or likely to be effective in stopping the virus’s spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Max Scherzer Smashes Salary Record in Deal With Mets
description: Showing off the team’s deep pockets, the Mets agreed to give Scherzer, a 37-year-old right-handed pitcher, a three-year contract that pays him $43.3 million a season.
content: After the Mets’ billionaire owner, Steven A. Cohen, flexed some of his financial might over the weekend with three new additions, he made his splashiest move yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Snowstorm Leaves Dozens Stranded for Days in a Remote U.K. Pub
description: A crowd had gathered on Friday night to listen to Noasis, an Oasis tribute band. On Monday, most of them were finally able to go home.
content: Up on a hill in Yorkshire, England, a crowd filled a pub on Friday to listen to an Oasis tribute band. Inside the pub, the Tan Hill Inn, the beers were cold, the fires were warming and the musicians were electric.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 29, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 29, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Catherine the Great Letter Up for Auction Shows Her Support for Inoculations
description: In a letter to be sold at auction this week, the Russian empress called for widespread access to a precursor of the smallpox vaccine.
content: As smallpox outbreaks ravaged communities in the 18th century, one of the first people in Russia to embrace a precursor to vaccines was Catherine the Great, the empress famed for promoting the latest knowledge in the arts and sciences from her throne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Union Vote at Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Overturned by Regional Labor Office
description: Amazon said in August that it intended to appeal to the national labor board if it did not prevail at the regional level, but it did not say Monday whether it would follow through.
content: A regional office of the National Labor Relations Board on Monday ordered a new union election at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, upholding a union challenge to a vote that the company won decisively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: As ‘Nutcracker’ Returns, Companies Rethink Depictions of Asians
description: Ballet companies are reworking the holiday classic partly in response to a wave of anti-Asian hate that has intensified during the pandemic.
content: A new character is featured in the Land of Sweets in Pacific Northwest Ballet’s “Nutcracker” this year: Green Tea Cricket, a springy, superhero-like figure meant to counter stereotypes of Chinese culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendell Jamieson
title: Arlene Dahl, Movie Star Turned Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 96
description: She had already started branching out when her film career was at its height, writing a syndicated column and launching a fashion and cosmetics business.
content: Arlene Dahl, who parlayed success as a movie actress in the 1940s and ’50s into an even more successful career as an author, beauty expert, astrologist, and fashion and cosmetics entrepreneur, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: A woman is charged with arson in quarantine hotel fire in Australia.
description: A 31-year-old mother and her two children had arrived in Queensland a few days ago.
content: A woman sent a quarantine hotel in Queensland, Australia, up in flames by lighting a fire under a bed in her room, according to police, triggering the evacuation of the building’s 163 occupants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial Opens, With Epstein at Its Center
description: A prosecutor described Jeffrey Epstein and his longtime girlfriend and associate, Ms. Maxwell, as “partners in crime.”
content: More than two years after Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a jail cell, Ghislaine Maxwell — the woman who prosecutors say helped him to recruit, groom and abuse young girls — went on trial on Monday in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Stout
title: Carrie P. Meek, U.S. Lawmaker Who Made Racial History, Dies at 95
description: She was the first Black person to represent Florida in the House since Reconstruction, and in five terms she fought for programs to create jobs.
content: Carrie P. Meek, who was spurred by memories of childhood discrimination and inspired by her heritage as she rose to political power in her native Florida and later in Washington, died on Sunday at her home in Miami. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Mark Guarino
title: Prosecutors: Jussie Smollett Faked Attack After Real Threat Was Ignored
description: In opening the trial, a prosecutor said Mr. Smollett had staged a hate crime because a death threat he received was not taken seriously enough at work.
content: The actor Jussie Smollett made himself the victim of a staged hate crime in 2019 to draw the attention of his colleagues on the television show “Empire” after he decided they had failed to take an earlier written threat seriously, a prosecutor said in a Chicago court on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Lee Elder, Who Broke a Golf Color Barrier, Dies at 87
description: In his prime he played in a league for Black players, but in 1975, at 40, he became the first African American to take part in the Masters tournament.
content: Lee Elder, who became the first African American golfer to play in the Masters tournament, a signature moment in the breaking of racial barriers on the pro golf tour, died on Sunday in Escondido, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Made in the U.S.A., but With a Supply-Chain Reboot
description: Facing delays, shortages and higher prices for raw materials, small manufacturers are finding new sources. Not all are able to pass along the costs.
content: Peak season has arrived for DPS Skis, a manufacturer and distributor of mountain sports gear in Salt Lake City. But this year, the winter challenges began far from the slopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nneka McGuire
title: Joaquina Kalukango and Amanda Williams on Creative Freedom
description: The “Slave Play” actress and the Chicago-based artist discuss generational gaps, success and the art that brought them each acclaim.
content: What does it mean for an artist to be free? And what does that freedom look like for a contemporary Black artist? Amanda Williams has recently been asking herself these very questions. A Chicago-based visual artist who trained as an architect, Williams, 47, is known for her pieces exploring the nuances of color, both racial and aesthetic. Her breakout work was “Color(ed) Theory,” a 2014-16 series in which she painted eight condemned houses on Chicago’s South Side in vivid, culturally coded shades, such as “Ultrasheen,” a dark turquoise that matches the hue of a Black hair-care product, and “Crown Royal Bag,” a purplish pigment that mirrors the packaging of a popular whisky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Scotland finds 6 cases of Omicron, but no sign its spread is ‘sustained.’
description: Officials in Scotland confirmed on Monday that six cases of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus had been recorded in the country and that some of those infected had not traveled recently, suggesting that there was community transmission. But they said there was no evidence that the transmission was “sustained or widespread.”
content: Officials in Scotland confirmed on Monday that six cases of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus had been recorded in the country and that some of those infected had not traveled recently, suggesting that there was community transmission. But they said there was no evidence that the transmission was “sustained or widespread.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Markets rise as investors reconsider the unknowns of the Omicron variant.
description: After tumbling on Friday, the S&P 500 gained more than 1 percent. Oil prices and bond yields also rose.
content: Global markets steadied on Monday, with stocks on Wall Street and oil prices gaining, as investors contemplated more carefully the knowns and unknowns of a new Covid-19 variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Matthew McConaughey Is Not Afraid to Go Down the Rabbit Hole
description: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”
content: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Virgil Abloh’s Celebrity Influence
description: Here are some memorable moments from Mr. Abloh's barrier-breaking career.
content: Here are some memorable moments from Mr. Abloh's barrier-breaking career.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Timeline of Jack Dorsey’s Twitter Tenure
description: A look at key moments from Dorsey’s tenure at the company.

author: By Emma Grillo
title: A Shower Bus Helps Those Without Access
description: People without regular access to bathing find help at Brooklyn Community Services' shower bus.
content: People without regular access to bathing find help at Brooklyn Community Services' shower bus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Sara Chodosh and Ben Casselman
title: Millennials Confront High Inflation for the First Time
description: Americans born after 1980 have been wrestling with sharp price increases for the first time since they’ve been old enough to notice.
content: Americans born after 1980 have been wrestling with sharp price increases for the first time since they’ve been old enough to notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton
title: What to Know About Mining in Congo
description: The government of Congo is trying to clean up cobalt mining in the country. Here’s the backstory.
content: The government of Congo is trying to clean up cobalt mining in the country. Here’s the backstory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Bulgaria?
description: Can you find Bulgaria on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European country with seven million people?
content: Can you find Bulgaria on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European country with seven million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Urges Vaccinations Amid Omicron Variant Concerns
description: President Biden called the new Omicron coronavirus variant “a cause for concern, not a cause for panic,” and urged Americans to get vaccinations and booster shots. The variant has not yet been detected in the United States.
content: President Biden called the new Omicron coronavirus variant “a cause for concern, not a cause for panic,” and urged Americans to get vaccinations and booster shots. The variant has not yet been detected in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: N.Y.C. Officials Reinforce Indoor Mask Guidance
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said the city was “doubling down” on its current advice that all residents wear masks in indoor public spaces, regardless of vaccination status. He also extended the city’s vaccine mandate to all child care workers.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said the city was “doubling down” on its current advice that all residents wear masks in indoor public spaces, regardless of vaccination status. He also extended the city’s vaccine mandate to all child care workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Scotland Reports Six Omicron Cases
description: Officials said that some of the cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant were not linked to travel, suggesting community transmission, but that there was no evidence that transmission was sustained or widespread.
content: Officials said that some of the cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant were not linked to travel, suggesting community transmission, but that there was no evidence that transmission was sustained or widespread.

title: Now, Cook for Yourself
description: Tejal Rao has a new recipe for paneer ajwaini tikka from the chef Chintan Pandya.
content: Good morning. Well, that’s done then: Thanksgiving sorted, Hanukkah started and holiday cookie season (above) on its way. I hope you’ll take some time for yourself this week, to cook the food you want to make.
